speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the breast mass? For example, is it painful, hard, or soft? How long have you noticed it?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a firm mass that I can feel in my left breast. I first noticed it about four weeks ago, and it seems to have grown quite a bit since then. There’s no pain associated with it at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the skin over the breast or any discharge from the nipple?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any changes in the skin or any discharge from the nipple. The area looks normal to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss, fatigue, or changes in your appetite recently?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any weight loss, fatigue, or changes in my appetite. I feel generally well aside from the mass.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous breast issues or family history of breast cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any significant past medical history or previous breast issues. There's also no family history of breast cancer that I'm aware of.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent imaging studies done, such as a mammogram or ultrasound, to evaluate the mass?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any imaging studies done yet. I just noticed the mass and decided to come in for an evaluation.

speaker: Doctor
text: I recommend we perform some imaging studies to get a better understanding of the mass. REQUEST TEST: Mammogram.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Smooth polylobulated mass in the left breast.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the mammogram results showing a smooth polylobulated mass, have you experienced any changes in your menstrual cycle or any hormonal treatments recently?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in my menstrual cycle recently, and I haven't been on any hormonal treatments either. My cycles have been regular as far as I can tell.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any breast tenderness or swelling in other areas of your body?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't experienced any breast tenderness, and there’s no swelling in other areas of my body. Everything else feels normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to the breast area that you can recall?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any recent injuries or trauma to the breast area that I can recall. Everything has been normal in that regard.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the size or shape of your breast, aside from the mass itself?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in the overall size or shape of my breast aside from the mass. It feels like the mass is the only thing that's changed.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent infections or illnesses that could be related to the breast mass?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any recent infections or illnesses that I can think of. I feel healthy otherwise.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the smooth polylobulated mass and your responses, I would like to perform a biopsy to determine the nature of the mass. Would you be comfortable with that?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I'm comfortable with that. I understand it's important to find out more about the mass. What can I expect during the biopsy procedure?

speaker: Doctor
text: The biopsy procedure typically involves using a needle to take a small sample of the mass for analysis. You may feel some discomfort, but it should be quick, and we'll provide local anesthesia to minimize any pain. After the procedure, we'll discuss the results and next steps.

speaker: Patient
text: That sounds straightforward. I appreciate the local anesthesia to help with any discomfort. How long will it take to get the results back?

speaker: Doctor
text: The results usually take about a week to come back. Once we have them, we can discuss the findings and any necessary treatment options. Do you have any other questions or concerns before we proceed with the biopsy?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any other questions at the moment. I'm just a bit anxious about the results, but I understand it's necessary to find out more. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: I understand that waiting for results can be anxiety-inducing. It's completely normal to feel that way. In the meantime, if you notice any changes or new symptoms, please don't hesitate to reach out.

speaker: Patient
text: Thank you for your understanding. I will definitely keep an eye on any changes and reach out if anything new comes up. I appreciate your support during this time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the smooth polylobulated mass and your responses, I would like to request a biopsy to determine the nature of the mass. Would you be comfortable with that?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I'm comfortable with that. I understand it's important to find out more about the mass. What can I expect during the biopsy procedure?

speaker: Doctor
text: The biopsy procedure typically involves using a needle to take a small sample of the mass for analysis. You may feel some discomfort, but it should be quick, and we'll provide local anesthesia to minimize any pain. After the procedure, we'll discuss the results and next steps. Now, before we proceed, I would like to ask if you have any allergies to medications or anesthesia?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't have any known allergies to medications or anesthesia. I've never had a reaction to any medications in the past.

speaker: Doctor
text: Thank you for confirming that. Have you ever had any previous surgeries or procedures related to your breasts?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any previous surgeries or procedures related to my breasts. This is the first time I've experienced anything like this.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the information you've provided and the mammogram results showing a smooth polylobulated mass, I would like to request a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. REQUEST TEST: Breast_Biopsy.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Image shows leaf-like structures with stromal cellular overgrowth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the biopsy results showing leaf-like structures with stromal cellular overgrowth, it appears that you may have a Phyllodes tumor, also known as a cystosarcoma phyllodes. DIAGNOSIS READY: Phyllodes tumor.
